Chip Dunning wrote:

> Because we of course desire a framework with known and long-standing 
> bugs in it, whose purpose to help others confront and fix their bugs.
> 
> Because when something is flawed, but good enough - we should never 
> strive to make it better for fear that it will spiral out of control 
> because of the dread disease "featuritis". Instead we should learn to 
> accept something, in all of its flaws, as "just good enough".
> 
> This email brought to you by the letter 'K' and the number '3'.

I think I get the point. Well played.
